title: 108_s434
content: The Act is titled the "Idaho Panhandle National Forest Improvement Act of 2004" and defines the term "Secretary." The Act titled the "Idaho Panhandle National Forest Improvement Act of 2004" defines the term "Secretary" as the Secretary of Agriculture. The Secretary is authorized to sell or exchange National Forest System land and improvements under specified terms and conditions. This includes parcels such as Granite/Reeder Bay, Priest Lake Parcel, North South Ski area, and Shoshone work camp. The Secretary has the authority to modify land descriptions for conveyance purposes. Consideration for land sale or exchange must be fair market value. Applicable laws govern National Forest System land conveyance. Valuation for land sales must adhere to Uniform Appraisal Standards. The Secretary has the authority to solicit offers for land sale or exchange under specific terms and conditions. Offers may be rejected if deemed inadequate or not in the public interest. The Secretary can sell land at public or private sale, including auctions, based on what is in the best interests of the United States. SEC. 4. DISPOSITION OF FUNDS. The Secretary shall deposit proceeds from sales or exchanges in the fund established under Public Law 90-171. The deposited amounts can be used for constructing a new ranger station in the Silver Valley portion of the Panhandle National Forest or for other facilities in the same forest. Proceeds from land sales or exchanges under this Act cannot be distributed. Proceeds from land sales or exchanges under this Act cannot be distributed to States or counties under any provision of law, or treated as money received from a national forest for specific purposes outlined in various Acts. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATION. Land transferred to the Secretary under this Act shall be managed in accordance with the Weeks Law and other laws related to the National Forest System. Property management regulations under title 7, Code of Federal Regulations, do not apply. All land described in section 3(a) is withdrawn from mining laws and public land orders are revoked. The Act revokes any public land order withdrawing land from appropriation under public land laws with respect to land conveyed by the Secretary. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out the Act.
